lead_paragraph: BUHL--Edward T. 81, died Monday, May 16, 2016. Loving husband of Lynn Minton. Predeceased by his wife of 43 years, Theresa Marie Guttieri. Brother of Mary Maiorana; father of Paul, Peter, Maria and Miriam Buhl. Stepfather of Tim, Charlie and Katherine Minton. Devoted grandfather to Cecilia, Elizabeth, Ethan Buhl; Nicholas Preller, Maxmilian and Julia Kracker; Maximilian and Heidi Grascher. Loving step- grandfather to Rachel, Jack, Alex, Gabrielle and Phillip Minton and James Bessoir. Ed graduated first in his class from Cathedral College in Brooklyn. He earned his law degree from St. John's University Law School, during which time he worked nights in the mailroom at IBM World Trade in New York City. Hired by IBM as an attorney in 1960, Ed rose through the ranks, eventually serving as General Counsel for IBM Europe (1979-1983) and finally Assistant General Counsel. Ed worked under IBM General Counsels Burke Marshall and Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, and his career covered several notable legal initiatives, including helping to draft the first United States affirmative action policy for businesses (1969) and negotiating IBM's position with respect to apartheid-era South Africa. He retired in 1992. Ed was a Renaissance man who loved opera, ballet, medieval art and architecture; spoke several languages, including French, Spanish and Latin; adored hiking, canoeing, bird watching, and nature photography. He was a wildflower expert and led tours for Teatown Lake Reservation in Ossining. He became an educator at the Cloisters, where he led tours and taught school children about medieval art and history. He had a wonderful sense of humor and was known for his kindness and sense of social justice. A private burial is planned. A memorial celebration of his life will be held at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to Teatown Lake Reservation, the Metropolitan Museum of Art (Cloisters) or Goddard Riverside Community Center, NYC. Ed's wife Lynn welcomes friends to their home at 350 Central Park West, NYC on Monday, May 23rd from 4-6pm and Tuesday, May 24th from 6-8pm. 1/3
